Some time ago, a website warned people about sharing their whereabouts online. The site said that when you post where you are, you're also telling everyone else. This can be a problem because not everyone is someone you want to meet. This is one of the downsides of sharing everything online.
The internet has many great opportunities, but it also has its dangers. We can share our lives with the whole world, but we have to be careful. Some people have learned this the hard way. A long time ago, a group of pioneers started sharing their lives online. They got into trouble, lost friends, and even got fired from their jobs.
One of these pioneers was a student named Justin Hall. He started posting about his life on the internet in 1994. He shared everything, from his thoughts to his photos. He even wrote about his relationships and his feelings. But one day, he had to take down his website because his partner didn't like it. This is a problem that many people face today.
Another example is Heather Armstrong, a young woman who worked in a software company. She wrote about her job on her blog, but an anonymous colleague sent the link to her bosses. She got in trouble and lost her job. This is what can happen when we share too much online.
The article is saying that the internet is not a separate world where we can be ourselves without consequences. Our online lives are connected to our real lives, and we have to be careful about what we share. We can say anything online, but that doesn't mean we should.

Some scientists were worried about a low-budget film called What the Bleep Do We Know? It's a mix of documentary and drama that shows how little we know about the universe. Scientists can't know everything, but some were upset about the film. They thought it was misleading and didn't provide enough evidence for some of its claims. The film says that water molecules can change shape when people think about them. This sounds amazing, but the evidence shown in the film is just some pictures of ice crystals that look different depending on the mood of the person talking to them. Many people find this convincing, but scientists want more proof.
The truth is that scientists are still discovering many new things about the universe. They've found that the universe is made of a type of matter that we don't know much about, and it's being pushed by a mysterious force called "dark energy". On a smaller scale, scientists have found that our brains can't process events as they happen, and we only become aware of them a half-second later. They've also found where modern humans came from and why they left their home to populate the world. Some scientists even think that the design of the universe is connected to the existence of life on Earth.
Despite what some people think, science is still a long way from understanding everything. In fact, we're getting closer to realizing that many things can never be fully understood. This has led some scientists to try to create a single theory that explains everything in the universe. For many of us, the universe is just incredible.

Writing novels is a big challenge, but writing short stories is a joy. It's like planting a forest versus a garden. Both are important and help me grow as a writer. When I finish a novel, I like to write some short stories. And when I finish a group of short stories, I want to write a novel. I never write short stories while writing a novel, and never write a novel while writing short stories. This helps me focus and makes my writing better. 
I started writing short stories in 1984. It was a new experience, but I enjoyed it. My first short story collection was called Tales from Abroad. I like writing short stories because they are quick to finish. It usually takes me a week to write a decent short story. This is different from writing a novel, which takes months or even years. Writing short stories is a change of pace and helps me stay fresh. I can write about small things, like an idea or an image, and see where it takes me. If the story doesn't work out, I don't worry. I can learn from my mistakes and use them in my next story. My short stories are like small footprints I leave behind. I remember where I wrote each one and how I felt. They are like guideposts to my heart, and I'm happy to share them with my readers.

Science is a complex subject that has both helped and harmed us. It has made our lives easier, but it has also caused problems. Scientists have tried to understand the world and the universe, but they still have a lot to learn. Sometimes, new discoveries replace old theories, and this can cause conflicts. Scientists are not always agreed on what they think they know. This book is about the ideas that have changed the way we think about science and the world. We will look at these ideas and consider their beauty and limitations. Science is always changing, and sometimes this leads to big changes in how we understand the world. Some people think that science is not good at explaining the world, but it has helped us make predictions and understand nature better. In the past, scientists thought they had already discovered everything, but then new discoveries were made. Today, scientists are working on a new theory that might explain everything. Science is important because it helps us control nature and make decisions about the future. We should pay attention to what scientists are doing because it affects our lives and the future of our planet.

'The sale of ebooks has slowed down in recent years. Some big publishers are even saying that ebook sales are falling. This has made people wonder if ebooks will replace print books. One person in the publishing industry said that the hype around ebooks might have led to bad decisions, and that their company lost confidence in the power of printed books. Despite this, many people still think that ebooks will replace print books. But the truth is that digital and print books can coexist. We still use both. This idea of one medium replacing another is not new. We've seen it with TV, radio, and the internet. People have always been worried that new technology will make old technology disappear. But usually, old technology finds new ways to stay popular.
We have a strong emotional connection to the things we use every day, like books, TVs, and computers. When a new technology comes along, it makes us think about what we used to have and what we're missing. This is why we often see a new appreciation for old things, like old books and their smell. We also like to tell stories about how technology changes our lives. We use stories to make sense of change. The story of the death of the book is a good example. It's a story that shows how we feel about new technology and how we're afraid of losing things that are important to us.'

For a year and a half, I woke up every weekday morning at 5:30. I brushed my teeth, made a cup of coffee, and sat down to write about how famous people throughout history managed their daily routines. I wanted to find out how they made time for their work, how they organized their days to be creative and productive. By looking at the daily habits of these people, I hoped to get a better understanding of their personalities and careers.
I believe that knowing what someone eats and when they eat can tell you a lot about who they are. I think that knowing someone's daily routine can also reveal a lot about their personality and work habits. This book is about the daily routines of famous and successful people, not just their final products. It's about how they managed their time, not just what they created.
I wrote this book because I struggle with the same issues in my own life. I want to know how to balance my creative work with my daily responsibilities. I want to know how to make time for everything I want to do. I don't have all the answers, but I hope to provide some examples of how other people have handled these challenges.
I wanted to show how big ideas can be broken down into small, daily tasks. I wanted to show how a person's daily routine can affect their work and vice versa. The title of my book is Daily Rituals, but I focused on people's daily routines. A routine can be ordinary and uninteresting, but it can also be a powerful tool for getting things done. A good routine can help you make the most of your time, energy, and optimism.
This book was inspired by my own procrastination. One day, I was supposed to write an article, but instead I spent the day tidying my office and making coffee. I started searching the internet for information on how other writers work. I found some interesting stories and decided to collect them in a blog. The blog was popular, and now I've turned it into a book.
I've tried to keep the book concise and diverse, with quotes from the people I'm writing about. I've also included a list of sources in the back of the book, so readers can learn more about the people and their routines.

Howard became interested in palaeontology when he was six years old. His family couldn't afford a holiday to Spain, so they went to the English coast instead. On the beach, Howard found an ammonite, a type of fossil. He knew he wanted to be a palaeontologist and, as he finished university, he decided he wanted to focus on the earliest times. He didn't like the flashy parts of the job, like dinosaurs, but he loved studying small creatures on rocks.
After completing his PhD, Howard worried about finding a job. He applied for a position at Tavistock College in London, but wasn't sure if he would get it. On the day of the interview, the professor who was supposed to chair the panel got into a fight with his wife and was late. The interview went ahead without him, and a colleague who didn't like Howard got him the job. Howard was surprised, but happy to have the job.
Howard found that his professional life was organized and predictable, but his personal life was chaotic. One day, his briefcase with important notes was stolen at a train station. He had to cancel a lecture and report the theft to the police. Later, he met a colleague who told him about a new collection of fossils at the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. This was an opportunity Howard couldn't miss, and he quickly changed his plans to visit the museum.

Charles Spence is a professor at Oxford University who studies how we experience food and drink. He thinks that the way we eat and drink is not just about the taste, but also about the surroundings and the company we keep. For example, eating with others can make us eat more. He has written a book about this called "The Perfect Meal".
Spence's lab is not high-tech, but he can still work with cooks and food companies to study how we eat. He gets funding from a big food company and has even worked with famous chefs like Heston Blumenthal. He has discovered some surprising things, like how music can affect what we taste. For example, higher-pitched music can make food taste sweeter, while lower-pitched music can make it taste bitter.
Spence's work is helping food companies make healthier food without changing the taste. He is also working with airlines to match music with food on planes. His family has fun trying out his experiments at home, like eating rabbit with the fur wrapped around the cutlery or playing with different sounds and lights while drinking different drinks.

Our brains are working harder than ever before. We're bombarded with information, fake news, and distractions, and we have to sort through it all to find what we need. At the same time, we're doing more things ourselves. Thirty years ago, travel agents would book our flights and salespeople would help us find what we needed in stores. Now we do most things ourselves. We're doing the work of 10 people while still managing our daily lives, families, careers, hobbies, and TV shows. Our smartphones help us do all this, but there's a problem. We think we're multitasking, but our brains aren't good at it. We're actually switching between tasks quickly, which can be tiring for our brains. This can make us less efficient and even stressed.
In fact, research shows that multitasking can increase stress hormones and make it harder to focus. Our brains can get easily distracted, especially by new things. This means that the part of our brain that helps us focus can get sidetracked. Just being able to multitask can make us less good at thinking and learning.
Some experts call this "info-mania." They say that having too much information and trying to focus on one task while doing other things can reduce our intelligence by almost 10 points. Even trying to learn new things while multitasking can make it harder to remember and understand.
Making decisions is also hard on our brains. Even small decisions can take up a lot of mental energy, and too many decisions can make us tired and confused. We might even make bad decisions because of it.
Many business leaders, scientists, and writers agree that email is a big problem. It's not the email itself, but the huge amount of communication we receive. We feel like we have to respond to every email, but it's hard to do that and get anything else done.

Some animals, like chimps and bats, do things that seem like they are trying to help each other. For example, a chimpanzee named Santino in a Swedish zoo used to break up concrete to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean or helpful? Some animals, like female bats, help other mothers who are having trouble giving birth. Are they being kind or just doing their job? 
Fifty years ago, scientists thought animals just did things without feelings or thoughts. But now, scientists are studying animal behavior and emotions. They are even writing books about it. This has started a big debate: can animals really think and feel like humans do? 
A recent experiment with cows showed that they enjoy solving problems. If cows can open a gate to get food, they seem to be happy. This makes us think about where we get our food and whether it's right to eat animals. 
Some scientists say we should stop eating meat because animals have feelings and thoughts. Others say we should just learn more about animal behavior and not make assumptions. 
The debate is not just about science, but also about what is right and wrong. It's a big question that may never be fully answered.

'Thinking critically is important when we read or listen to something to understand it better. Adrian West, a researcher, says that people used to think that arguing was a way to find the truth. However, technology is changing the way we think. We are exposed to more information, but this can make it harder to think clearly. West says that we are often overwhelmed by too much information and opinions.
Reading is becoming less popular, and some people think this is affecting our ability to think critically. Patricia Greenfield, a professor, says that we are spending too much time on visual media like video games and TV, and not enough time reading. This can make it harder to think deeply and make good decisions.
Technology can be both good and bad for our thinking. For example, a computer game can help us think critically or make us think less critically. Reading on the internet can help us analyze information, but clicking on too many links can make it hard to think deeply.
James Paul Gee, a professor, says that video games can be a good tool for learning. They can help us develop important skills like decision-making and analysis. He believes that we should not think that video games are always bad for kids. In fact, they can be very helpful.
It's important to understand how technology affects our thinking and analysis. As reading and math scores are declining, we need to take a closer look at technology and how it affects our minds.'

Matthew Crawford is a motorcycle mechanic who used to work in offices. He writes books about how we should live. His latest book is about the problems of modern life. He noticed that we're constantly being interrupted by advertisements and messages on our phones. This makes it hard for us to think and remember things. We're also less likely to talk to strangers because we're always trying to avoid distractions.
Crawford thinks that we're losing the ability to focus on what's important because we're too busy looking at our phones. He says that we're more aware of the things we could be doing, but we're not doing them because we're too busy staring at screens. This is not a new problem - people have been worried about it since the invention of the telegraph.
Crawford thinks that technology has made it easier for us to avoid dealing with real people and things. We'd rather send a text message to a friend instead of talking to them face-to-face. He gives the example of a gym where people used to listen to music together, but now everyone listens to their own music on headphones. This has made the gym a less social place.
Crawford suggests that we need to find ways to engage with the world in a more meaningful way. He thinks that doing things that require skill and attention, like cooking or playing sports, can help us do this. These activities force us to focus on the present moment and deal with the world around us. When we do this, we can see that manufactured experiences, like video games or social media, are not as satisfying as real experiences.
Crawford's solution is to find ways to use our judgment and pay attention to what's important. This can be tiring, but it makes it easier to focus on what matters.

'What do you do for a living?' It's a common question, but it's not always easy to answer. When you're a philosopher, it's even harder. Saying you're a philosopher can sound pretentious, like you're trying to be special or superior to others. But this isn't true. Philosophers are just people who think deeply about the world and try to understand it. They're not better than anyone else.
The idea that philosophers are special comes from ancient Greece, where philosophers like Aristotle and Socrates were respected for their wisdom. They believed that thinking deeply about the world was the most important thing you could do. Today, people still think that philosophy is about being smart and thinking deeply, but it's not just that. It's about looking at the world in a new way and trying to understand it.
Some philosophers have become too focused on their own special ideas and don't talk to anyone else about them. This makes it hard for people to understand what philosophy is really about. But philosophy is actually very practical. It's about looking at the things we do every day and asking if they're really important. It's about thinking about what we believe and why we believe it.
As an ethicist, I study how we should behave and what is right and wrong. But I think there's more to philosophy than just making rules. I think it's about exploring big questions and thinking about how we live our lives. By doing this, we can learn more about ourselves and the world around us.

'Food is an important part of our lives, and many people enjoy thinking about what and how we eat. However, philosophers haven't always talked about food in a serious way. Instead, they have used food as a metaphor for other topics, like learning. Sometimes, they discuss food, but only to make a point about something else. 
One ancient Greek philosopher, Epicurus, believed in enjoying life and avoiding pain. He didn't just talk about food, but about all aspects of life. Today, his name is often associated with a love of eating and drinking, and even restaurants and food shops use it to make their products sound appealing.
Food is also a social and cultural thing. The food we eat comes from our community and is often shared with others. This is why food is an important topic for philosophers to explore. 
When people write about food, they often talk about how it tastes. But, surprisingly, there isn't much written about how we perceive the taste of food. This is an area that needs more attention. 
Food can also be beautiful, like art or music. Some people think that, with the rise of modern cooking, food has become an important part of aesthetic discussions. However, food is eaten and destroyed, unlike art, which can be preserved and admired over time. 
There are also many ethical questions about food, such as what we should eat and why. Philosophers will always ask these questions and explore the answers. 
Finally, food can bring people together, whether it's in a restaurant or at home. Home cooks have a special responsibility to their guests, while professional chefs have obligations to their employers and the food itself. Food can even help bridge cultural gaps by bringing people together to share meals and learn about each other's cultures.'

Rob Daviau, an American, designs special board games called 'legacy' games. He wanted to make games more exciting and challenging. He thought, 'Why can't games have a story? Why can't our choices affect the game in the next session?' He created a new version of a classic game called Risk, called Risk Legacy. In this game, players make permanent changes to the board. They might tear up cards, draw on the board, or open new rule packets. The game is played over several sessions, and players can see the results of their choices.
Daviau was asked to help create a legacy version of another popular game, Pandemic. Players work together to cure diseases. His next project was a game called SeaFall. Players become sailors and explore the world. Legacy game designers need to think about all the possible choices players can make to make the game exciting and fun.
To test the game, designers play it many times to see how it unfolds. One tester, Jaime Barriga, said it takes a lot of time and effort. 'You have to play the game many times to make sure it's fun and exciting.'
Daviau didn't expect legacy games to become popular. He thought it would be a niche idea. But many players loved the concept. One player, Russell Chapman, said it's the biggest advance in game design in years. 'It's exciting to learn new things and make new choices,' he said.
Another player, Ben Hogg, said the appeal of an unfolding adventure is more important than worrying about the game's longevity. 'It's like watching a TV series,' he said.
Pandemic creator Matt Leacock compared the legacy design process to writing a novel. 'You need to plan the beginning and end, but also be flexible,' he said. Daviau wants to see where others take the idea, but he's also excited to play the games himself.
Colby Dauch, a game publisher, thinks the legacy format has changed the way we think about board games. 'It's a new way to experience a game,' he said.

One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at a zoo in New Zealand. He climbed out of the water, crossed the floor, and squeezed into a small drain that led to the ocean. This story was shared online and was very popular. People enjoy imagining that animals are like us, and octopuses are especially interesting because they are very smart and have bodies that are very different from ours. How can octopuses open jars, recognize faces, and even play games? Some scientists think that we don't give animals enough credit for their intelligence. They say that we often think animals are not as smart as we are, but this is not true. Animals can do many things that we thought were unique to humans, such as thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, and understanding what others are thinking. Octopuses, for example, can solve problems and even play with toys.
In the past, people thought that animals were very intelligent and could be put on trial for crimes. Even Charles Darwin, the scientist who discovered evolution, believed that the difference between humans and animals is just a matter of degree, not kind. However, in the 20th century, some scientists thought that animals were just machines that responded to stimuli or had useful instincts. This changed how people thought about animals and how they treated them. Now, scientists are learning more about animal intelligence and how it is similar to human intelligence. They are designing tests that are specific to each species and its abilities. For example, squirrels can remember where they hide nuts, but they might struggle with human memory tests. An octopus might test humans on their ability to change color like an octopus does.
The story of Inky the octopus is a good example of how people are becoming more interested in animal intelligence. The scientist who wrote about Inky is skeptical about whether Inky really escaped on his own, but he thinks that the story can help people appreciate how smart octopuses are.

'Robots are changing the way we work and live. They are no longer just machines that can do simple tasks. Experts say that robots will soon be used in many areas, including healthcare, education, and even our homes. This change will be big and will affect many jobs. Some people think that robots will take over many jobs, but experts say that this is not necessarily true. They believe that robots will create new jobs that require special skills, such as programming and maintenance.
A company in Australia has developed a robot that can lay bricks faster than a human. A robot in a supermarket in the US ensures that shelves are stocked and priced correctly. Robots are getting smarter and more efficient, and they will soon be able to work alongside humans.
Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert on robotics, says that robots will have a big impact on the job market. He believes that many people will need to retrain to adapt to the changes. He also thinks that robots will create new opportunities for companies that are prepared to take advantage of this shift.
In the future, we can expect to see robots that can walk and talk like humans. This will change the way we live and work. It is important that we prepare for this change by investing in education, particularly in subjects like science, technology, engineering, and maths (STEM).'

'Why do people climb mountains?' This is a question that has puzzled many. Some people might think it's crazy to risk their lives to climb a big mountain. But for climbers, it's about the adventure and the fun. Climbing can be a way to challenge yourself and feel free. It's like playing a game with rules, and the way you play depends on the game. Some people love climbing because it makes them feel alive. But it can also be scary and confining at times. For example, being stuck in a tent during a storm is not very liberating.
Some people think that climbing is in our nature. We have always climbed and will always climb. It's a way to test our limits and push ourselves. Others believe that climbing helps us develop important qualities like courage, humility, and respect for nature. It can also help us develop virtues like perseverance and self-reliance.
Climbing can be done in different ways, and some people prefer to do it alone. They have to be very committed to their goal to succeed. This can be a big challenge, but it can also be very rewarding.
Climbing is not just about the physical activity, but also about being in the moment and feeling connected to nature. It's like a form of meditation. Some people even think that climbing can help us reach a state of perfect peace, like in Zen philosophy.
When we ask why people climb, we can consider all these different perspectives. It's a complex question, but it's an important one to explore.'

Alfred Brendel was a famous pianist who performed classical music for many years. He was a serious and focused person who loved to play and record music. Brendel didn't teach many students, but he was impressed by a young boy named Kit Armstrong when he asked for lessons. Kit was only 14 years old, but he played the piano very well and even recorded a CD of his own music. Brendel was impressed by Kit's talent and agreed to teach him.
Kit is now 19 years old and is still learning from Brendel. He is a hard worker and likes to learn new things, such as languages, math, and computer programming. He also likes to play tennis and compose his own music. Brendel says that Kit has a great memory and can play the piano very well. He is also very good at listening to his own playing and can make changes to improve it.
Brendel is careful not to put too much pressure on Kit, as he doesn't want him to get too stressed. He says that Kit is still young and needs time to develop his skills. Brendel himself is now 80 years old and has stopped performing, but he still loves music and is happy to share his knowledge with Kit.

When I was a child, I thought all gardens were beautiful and peaceful. My grandfather's garden was special because it was near a river. You couldn't see the river, but you could hear the water and the birds singing. I thought all gardens were like this. My grandfather's garden wasn't very big or fancy. He didn't have a greenhouse like some of his neighbors, who made their own greenhouses from old windows. My father was a quiet person, but he had a good sense of humor. He liked to say funny things, like "It's immaterial to me." He was never very ambitious, but he was good at fixing things around the house. My parents moved to a new house only once, but my mother liked to buy new furniture. One day, they got a piano, but I was never allowed to play it. My sister took lessons instead. When I asked my mother why I couldn't play, she said I wouldn't have practiced. I liked to go to the river with my fishing net and imagine I was in another world. I would walk along the riverbank, looking for a good spot to take off my shoes and put my net in the water. I wanted to leave school as soon as possible, but it seemed unlikely until my father said there was a job opening for an apprentice gardener. I was surprised, but I think my father wanted me to be happy.

I'm on the Scottish island of Muck with Lawrence MacEwen. The wind is strong, but he's comfortable here. He's been living on the island for a long time. We're walking down the hill when he points to another island, Eigg, and says it gets a lot more rain than we do. We're going to move his sheep. He tells me some interesting facts about the island, like how it's volcanic and has been home to his family for 3000 years.
As we move the sheep, his dog, Tie, isn't doing a good job. Lawrence is not happy. The island is a family business. His wife, Jenny, helps with the farm, his son manages the cottages, and his daughter runs the hotel. They love that their boys can play outside and sail on the summer days.
Life on the island can be challenging. We don't have electricity all the time, and there's no mobile phone signal. But we make do. One evening, I'm waiting for the lights to turn on, and the next morning, Mary is setting out breakfast by torchlight. I get used to it.
The island is a special place. We have a concert with some musicians who come by boat. Everyone enjoys it. That night, Lawrence tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. Her father bought a farm on another island without even seeing it, and Jenny was sent to manage it. She didn't know much about farming, but she was good at typing.
I eat well on the island, and Mary sends me to get fresh fish from a fisherman. We have it for dinner, and it's delicious. The next day, I take a ferry to my next destination. The ferry ride was uncertain because of the weather, but I'm glad I made it.

'In the past, the video game industry was not easy to get into. People thought it was just a hobby for young people. But now, the industry is growing and taking itself seriously. To work in this industry, you need a lot of skill, patience, and hard work. Jim Donelly, a games expert, says that it's difficult to get a job at a big company, but there are still opportunities. He says that the industry needs people who can design games, not just those who can make big decisions. 
To get into this industry, you can try making your own games. Jim says that the tools are available and that you won't get a job if you haven't made something. Another expert, John Field, agrees that making games is important, but he thinks it's more complicated than that. He says that there are many people who want to work in games, but few who have the skills and talent needed. 
Can you make it on your own? John says it's difficult, but a good course can help. Most people start by working as programmers or artists and then move up the career ladder. They are interested in all forms of entertainment and have a good understanding of the arts. They may have worked for a few years before deciding that games is what they want to do. 
Finally, connections can help. It's important to network and make connections in the industry. The stereotype of the teenage boy playing games has changed, and now games are enjoyed by people of all ages. Smartphones have made it easy to play games and social media has made it easy to connect with others who share the same interests. John believes that there is still plenty of room for growth and that games can be a great way to learn new things.'

'I've always loved playing football. My dad encouraged me to play when I was a kid, but he didn't force me. I had a friend who played with us, but his dad was very pushy and made him feel bad about his skills. My friend stopped playing football and never played again. I'm glad it wasn't like that for me.
When I score a goal from far away, people say it's just luck, but I've worked hard to improve my skills. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice a lot. I think it's important to enjoy learning new skills.
I used to play many sports at school, but football was my favourite. I want my son to enjoy learning too, so we're already reading books to him, even though he's still too young to sit still for long. I hope he doesn't follow me in loving football too much.
When I started my professional football career, our manager helped us younger players move up to the first team, but he didn't make a big fuss about it. We knew we had to work hard to succeed. We lost our first game, and a famous TV presenter said we couldn't win anything with young players. That made us more determined to prove ourselves.
I rely on my close friends and family, but having a lot of money can sometimes cause problems. People sometimes say I should help my parents financially, but I think they would be offended if they felt they were on the payroll. My mum loves her job as a hairdresser, and I like using my money to make things easier for the people around me.
After I stop playing football, I plan to take a break and do things I haven't been able to do before, like go skiing. I want to do it right after I stop playing, but I'm worried about getting hurt and not being able to play football again.'

We lived at Reef Point because of Sam Carter, my father's agent in Los Angeles. My father and Sam worked together, and Sam found a cheap place for us to live. This was because my father couldn't write well when we were in Los Angeles. The beach at Reef Point was not popular with tourists because the road was not nice and there was a nicer place nearby. But in the summer, more people came to the beach. My father was working hard to write a script, and I would often go to the beach with my dog Rusty. Rusty was a stray who liked to dig and bring things to me. Sometimes, he would find things that didn't belong to him, and I would have to give them back to their owners. Rusty loved the beach and swimming. He would always swim with me, even though he wasn't very good at it. One day, my father went to Los Angeles to deliver the script, and Rusty and I spent the day swimming and watching the surfers. There was one surfer who was very good, and she talked to me after her last wave. She asked me why I didn't join the surfers, and I said I didn't have a surfboard. She suggested I could buy one, but I didn't have the money. She asked if my father was American, and I said no. She had heard of my father, Rufus Marsh, because he wrote a famous book called "Tall as the Morning". She read the book and was interested in talking to me.

Violet Hetherington stood in a long queue at the dock in Southampton. She was waiting to board the Queen Caroline, but the queue wasn't moving. Her friend Annie had told her to arrive late, but it seemed that was bad advice. Suddenly, an announcement came over the loudspeaker: there was a problem with the computer system. The atmosphere among the passengers became gloomy. Some people were getting impatient, but others tried to stay calm. They had paid a lot of money for this trip, and they wanted it to be perfect. Violet was feeling frustrated. She had lost her phone, which meant she couldn't contact the taxi company to see if she had left it behind. She couldn't even ring her son Harry to ask him to help her. She was worried about being stuck in New York without a phone. A nice couple behind her in the queue offered to let her use their phone to call her son. Violet left a message asking her neighbor Kristina to check if the phone was at her flat. She was relieved that Kristina could help her. Eventually, the queues started moving, and Violet went to the window to hand over her documents. She was disappointed when she saw the ship's foyer. It looked like a fancy hotel, but not as nice as she had expected. Violet followed the signs to the elevators, which were decorated with mirrors and crowded with passengers. She was squashed in the lift, but finally reached her room on the 12th floor. She was relieved to find that it had a balcony, which was what she had wanted. She had paid a lot of money for this trip, and she was determined to enjoy it.

'John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction. He was looking for pictures to use in a book about a neighborhood in Chicago. Instead, he found 30,000 photos taken by a street photographer named Vivian Maier. Maier was a private person who loved taking pictures of everyday life. She was a nanny in Chicago and took pictures of the people and places she saw every day. Maloof has a big collection of Maier's work, including cameras, film, prints, and videos. He and his friend are trying to learn more about Maier's life and work. They talked to people who knew her and looked at her pictures. Maier was born in New York and grew up in France. She moved to Chicago and worked as a nanny. She loved taking pictures and was always carrying a camera with her. She took pictures of people, buildings, and street scenes. Her work is very good and people are interested in learning more about her. Maloof wants to share her work with the world and make sure she is remembered.'

Eleanor Catton is a young writer who has written a big book called The Luminaries. It's a murder mystery set in New Zealand in the 1860s. The story is very complex, with 20 main characters and over 800 pages. Eleanor wanted to give each character a chance to be important in the story. When I asked her how she felt about being successful at such a young age, she said it's nice because people in her small country feel proud of her. She also said that some people assume her book is not deep or meaningful, but she wants to show that it is.
Eleanor told me that she wrote the book in a special way, with each part getting shorter as the story goes on. She wanted to create a book with patterns that readers could find if they looked closely. The book is exciting and has a good plot, and Eleanor said she didn't plan it out beforehand. She just wrote herself into a difficult situation and then tried to get out of it. She also wanted to make the book fun to read.
I asked Eleanor if she would like to write for TV, and she thought it could be cool. She loves talking about her writing and New Zealand. She said that when she comes to Britain, she notices that her imagination changes because of the different landscape. But for now, she will stay in New Zealand, which inspires her to write more books.

'Jonny Kinkead has been making guitars for over 40 years. As a boy, he loved playing the guitar and building things with his dad's tools. He learned to play his brother's guitar when he was 11 and then wanted to learn the bass guitar. Jonny was always interested in how things work and how to make them better. He studied guitars and learned how to make different sounds by using different types of wood.
After school, Jonny went to university to study architecture, but he didn't finish the course. He realized that he was too individualistic and wanted to do something more creative. He started building guitars and selling them, but it wasn't easy. He had to work part-time jobs to make ends meet and it took him a while to get his guitars known.
Now, Jonny is one of the best guitar-makers in the UK. He thinks that it's easier for new guitar-makers to develop a career today because people recognize the quality of UK-made guitars. He believes that taking courses is important, but also thinks that trial and error is the best way to learn. He learned by trying different things and making mistakes.'

'Talking about the weather is a common topic in English conversations. Many people start their conversations with a comment about the weather. This is because, as the famous writer Dr. Johnson said, 'When two English people meet, their first talk is of the weather.' This is still true today. However, many people try to explain why English people talk so much about the weather, but they often get it wrong. They think that English people are really interested in the weather. But that's not the case.
The American writer Bill Bryson thinks that the English weather is not exciting or interesting. He says that there are no big storms or dramatic weather events in England. On the other hand, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees. He thinks that the English weather is fascinating because it is always changing and unpredictable.
My research shows that both Bryson and Paxman are wrong. Talking about the weather is not really about the weather at all. It's a way for English people to talk to each other without feeling awkward. We use phrases like 'Nice day, isn't it?' or 'Ooh, it's cold!' to start conversations or fill gaps in the conversation. These phrases are like a secret code that helps us feel more comfortable with each other.
There are certain situations when we use this code. We might use it as a greeting, to break the ice and start a conversation. We might use it to fill a silence or to move on from a difficult topic. It's easy to see why people might think that English people talk about the weather all the time, but really, it's just a way to be friendly and polite.'

Alice Leader is a teacher who loves history and writing. She took her students on a trip to Hadrian's Wall in Britain to show them how amazing the Romans were to build a wall 120 km long and 5 meters high 1900 years ago. The students were curious about why the Romans built the wall. Alice wanted to find a good book to help them understand, but she couldn't find one. So, she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started writing novels in 2001. She liked writing more than teaching because it's less tiring. Alice's goal is to write books that are fun and interesting for children. She wants to show them that there's more to life than just negative or fantasy stories.
Alice used to teach English and History together. She loved seeing students go from being bored to being interested in learning. Now, she writes books that make children want to read more. Alice started writing because she wanted to fill a gap in children's books. She was inspired by a suggestion from her head teacher and a course she took. She wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby-to-be and got great feedback from her fellow students. With the help of her husband, who is a critic and editor, Alice was able to finish her first novel. He helped her make the story better by changing the sentence structure and suggesting new ideas.

'Two brothers, Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, are famous triathletes. They decided to take part in a special race to raise money for charity. The race was between a car and a bike, and the brothers were competing against each other. Jonny drove a car on the roads, while Alistair rode a bike across the countryside. They started at a beautiful lake in Yorkshire and had to finish at the highest road in the area.
Jonny was excited to be in the car, saying it was nice and warm inside. Alistair was dressed in warm clothes and was confident he would win because he had seen Jonny drive before and wasn't sure he would make it. The race was challenging, with steep hills and narrow roads. Jonny got stuck behind a tractor, while Alistair had to get off his bike and carry it up a hill. But Alistair was determined and kept going.
In the end, Alistair reached the finish line first, and Jonny was disappointed. He said he was gutted to lose to his brother.'

'When I play on Centre Court at Wimbledon, I notice the silence. I bounce the ball on the soft grass, and it makes no noise. I serve and hit the ball, and I hear the echo of my own shot. The quiet of the court helps me focus on my game. I try to ignore everything else and just think about the match. The silence is broken by applause and cheers when a point is finished. I hear them, but it feels like they're coming from far away.
I've always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My coach, my uncle Toni, told me it was the biggest tournament. When I was 14, I thought about playing there one day and winning. Before 2008, I played and lost to Roger Federer twice. The second time I lost, I was very upset. I knew I could have done better. My coach told me not to cry, that there would be other chances.
I'm a professional athlete, and I know my career is short. I want to make the most of it. I had a second chance in 2008, and I was determined to do better. The night before the final, we didn't talk about the match at dinner. I was already thinking about it in my head, and I wanted to keep it to myself until the match started.'

'A young English woman named Jane Goodall went to Africa in 1957. She was very excited to be there and wrote to her family, 'I am living in the Africa I have always dreamed of.' Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became a famous scientist, journalist, and activist. She is known for her work with chimpanzees.
In 1963, a well-known magazine and TV channel made a big deal about Jane's research on chimpanzees. She wrote books for children and adults, and one of her books became a bestseller. Many people know Jane Goodall because of her work, but some people think that her fame has hidden what she really achieved.
Jane Goodall is a very important scientist. She spent 40 years studying chimpanzees and found out many new things about them. Before she started her research, people didn't know that chimpanzees ate meat, used tools, or had emotions like humans. She also found that chimpanzees have their own cultures and communities, just like humans.
Jane Goodall's book about chimpanzees is considered the most important book on the subject. Her work changed the way scientists study animals and helped people understand more about themselves. Even when Jane was a child, she showed signs that she would become a scientist. When she was five, she hid in a henhouse to see how hens lay eggs. This might have been the start of her career as a biologist.'

Shirley Ford is a voiceover artist. She can speak in many different voices. She talks to me like a cheeky 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, an old Scottish woman, and even a fast-talking alien. She has done many voiceovers, including ones about back injuries. She has to learn to pronounce medical terms quickly.
Shirley says that many actors think they can do funny voices, but it's not just about that. You have to bring the script to life for people who can't see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceovers, but they often don't get the parts because they're used to acting with their whole bodies.
Shirley studied drama and started doing voiceovers by accident. She got a big part in a cartoon and realized she was good at it. She learned to create different voices and sounds from the back of her throat. She collects new voices by watching children's TV and cartoons.
Shirley has worked on many projects, from educational videos to vacuum cleaner ads. She says the trick is to smile while talking, which makes her voice sound bright and cheerful. She loves working on animation projects because it's like a holiday.
The competition for work is tough, but Shirley says it's important to have a good showreel, which is a recording that shows what you can do. She recommends attending specialist workshops and having a passion for sound and voices.
Shirley is very good at her job and has worked hard to get where she is. She loves her job and is obsessed with voices. Sometimes, she even talks like the characters she's performing for hours or days afterwards. Her children are used to their mum talking in different voices.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. It's a job that many people dream about as kids, like being a pilot or a doctor. But most people give up on these childhood dreams and choose more realistic careers, like being a lawyer or an engineer. It's hard to believe that someone can make a living by drawing simple doodles, but some people do it. 
I'm one of those people. I always loved drawing and making comics as a kid. I even drew for my school newspaper. After college, I studied graphic design and then started showing my work to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper that wanted my cartoons. I drew a few ideas and they liked them, so I started selling them. It's not necessary to have a university degree or a lot of money to become a cartoonist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. 
Of course, it's not easy. There are many people who want to be cartoonists, so you need to be good at what you do. I've done many different types of cartoons, like political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I've also been a writer, a caricaturist, and a designer. 
The business side of being a cartoonist is important. In the past, many cartoonists had regular jobs drawing for newspapers and magazines. But now, most cartoonists work for themselves. That means you need to be good at selling your work and finding new customers. I've seen many cartoonists who are not very good at drawing but are very good at business do well. 
Some people worry about someone stealing their ideas, but it's not a big deal. You just need to put a little 'c' for 'copyright' on your work and you're protected. If someone does steal your work, it might even be a good thing! It could make your work popular and help you get more customers.

Twenty years ago, I moved house and got rid of many things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. I didn't know why I wanted to get rid of it, but I did. I took it to the dump and was about to throw it away when a young man asked me if I was sure I wanted to get rid of it. I said yes, but then felt bad. He asked if he could have it and I said okay. Later, I felt sad about getting rid of it.
Years later, I received an email from someone who restores guitars. He said he had found my guitar and wanted to sell it back to me. I was surprised and happy. It turned out that the man who took it from the dump had sold it to someone else, and it had been passed around. The guitar had a label on the back with my name on it, so the man was able to find me.
I had forgotten that my dad used to put labels on everything I owned, including my guitar. My parents had wanted me to learn classical guitar, but I didn't make much progress. I switched to electric guitar and played simple songs. When I took the guitar out of the box, I remembered my 16th birthday and how happy I was to get it.
I picked up the guitar and felt comfortable playing it. My fingers knew what to do, and I felt like playing. The electric guitar is not a solo instrument, so I might need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe there are other people who have had a similar experience to mine. We could call ourselves "The Regainers"!

Sleep is an important topic that has been discussed a lot lately. I wrote a book about people who have trouble sleeping and the effects it has on their minds, bodies, and moods. When I interviewed people who struggle with sleep, they told me that sleep is crucial for their well-being. It's great that people are finally paying attention to sleep. But I think we should also talk about dreams. We often cut off the last hour or two of sleep when we wake up early, which means we lose a lot of our most vivid dreams. These dreams can be very powerful and memorable. Researchers have found that when people don't get enough REM sleep, they make up for it the next night. This means that dreams are important. In the past, people thought that dreams were a way to understand the mind, but now we know that they are more about the physical workings of the brain. 
Dreams can be useful for creative people like actors, writers, and directors. A study found that these people are better at remembering and using their dreams. It makes sense that filmmakers need to use their dreams, since film is a very imaginative medium. But I think that everyone needs to use their dreams, not just creative people. We all need to think creatively and come up with new ideas. Dreams can help us do this by bringing together things we know and creating new connections. For example, a researcher found that when people are woken up during REM sleep, they come up with more original ideas than when they are woken up during other stages of sleep. I find that I write better when I wake up after a good dream. Even a bad dream can give me ideas and help me think more clearly. We all need to think creatively, so we all need to dream.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London and moved to a small town in the south-west of England. She has a studio with a beautiful view of the sea. The walls are filled with empty frames and photos of her two daughters. You might expect to see many of her own paintings, but they're all gone as soon as she finishes them. This is because she's very good at copying famous paintings. She's been doing this for 30 years and has copied many famous works by artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so good that art experts often think they're the originals.
Susie's clients are mostly galleries and private collectors. Some of them buy her copies because they love art, while others do it to show off. She doesn't reveal the names of most of her clients, but she says that some famous people even pass off her copies as originals. However, Susie is honest about what she does. She makes sure her copies are as good as possible, but she always signs her name on the back of the canvas.
Some people might think it's strange that Susie doesn't create her own art. She's very good at copying, but she's not sure if her own paintings would be as good. She has tried to create her own art, but it didn't turn out well. She thinks it's like trying to cook a meal after a lifetime of eating at a top restaurant. Susie is a perfectionist and is happy making a good living from copying famous paintings.

Ellen MacArthur loves the sea and racing. She was obsessed with being the fastest person on the water from a young age. When she's on her boat, she feels like she's one with it. But when she's on land, she feels trapped and wants to get back to the sea. After finishing second in a big sailing race, she took me on a tour of her boat, showing me how she prepared for her long journey. She was very proud of how well she had planned everything, from the food to the medical supplies. She took care of her boat like it was her home.
Ellen has a new message now. She sees the world as a small, beautiful thing that we need to take care of. She believes we need to stop using up all our resources and start thinking about the future. She's been talking to governments and businesses about this and has even started a charity to help young people think about how to make the world a better place. She misses the adventure of sailing, but she feels like this new mission is even more important.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to climb Mount Everest, the highest mountain in the world. If he succeeds, he will be the youngest person to do so. Jordan's parents, Paul and Karen, are also climbers and are helping him on his journey. They want to inspire other young people to go outside and be active.
Jordan has already climbed five of the Seven Summits, the highest points on each continent. Climbers who have climbed Everest before think that it's not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the mountain. They say that a young person might not be emotionally strong enough and might not have enough experience to make good decisions.
Jordan's parents know that people might be worried about their son's safety, but they are experienced climbers themselves and are careful to consider the risks. They also think that Jordan is becoming stronger and more responsible every day.
I asked Jordan why he wants to climb Everest, and he said that he just wants to achieve his goal. His father, Paul, said that they don't want to make a big deal out of this just for the sake of being famous. They want to make sure that Jordan still enjoys climbing and doesn't get too caught up in trying to set records.
If Jordan decides that he no longer wants to climb mountains, his parents will stop the project and focus on other activities, like playing basketball.

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's unlikely they're listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but ask someone if they know who Brahms was and they might not know. I'm studying music, but my friends and I don't know much about classical music. If you don't know who wrote the music, you're unlikely to buy their recordings. The statistics are not good for classical music. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music events, and the average classical recording sells only 300 copies.
I think classical music just doesn't appeal to most people, especially teenagers. Some people blame TV and video games for this, but I don't think that's the reason. The truth is that classical music is not interesting to many people. I know some teenagers who love classical music, but they are a minority.
As a musician, I play in an orchestra, but I'm not a big fan of classical music myself. I like many types of music. So, why don't teenagers like classical music? One reason is that classical music is slow and complex, and we like fast-paced music. We also have trouble paying attention for more than a few minutes, which is too short for most classical music. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music requires time and concentration.
Pop music also deals with topics that are more interesting to teenagers than classical music. Classical music is powerful, but it doesn't talk about the things that worry us. The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would make music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. Nowadays, you can find any music you want on the internet, and classical music is not a big part of our lives.
I don't know why people like classical music more as they get older, but I do know that if your parents like something, you're less likely to like it too. Some people think that schools are to blame for the lack of interest in classical music among teenagers, but there are many kids who enjoy playing classical music in school. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. Classical music is their favorite when they perform, but it's not their usual choice. The two things have become separate. When we want to relax, it's usually pop music we listen to.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother's car and looked at Almonside School. She was a bit upset. Her mother was getting out of the car too, but Bonnie didn't care if she heard her. Bonnie's mother knew how she felt.
Mrs. Wyndham looked around and saw that Almonside School was a bit strange. It had different buildings hidden among the trees. There were signs saying 'Science block', 'gymnasium', and 'riding centre'. Bonnie saw the sign for the riding centre and got interested. Her mother saw it too and said, 'This way.'
Bonnie followed her mother to the headmaster's study. Then her mother started talking to the headmaster while Bonnie waited outside. Bonnie didn't like waiting. She thought she might get kicked out of the school anyway, so she might as well explore. She went to the riding centre, where she saw some nice old buildings and a big place for riding horses. There were no people around, but Bonnie was careful not to disturb the horses. She liked horses and wanted to make sure they were happy.
Bonnie saw a small pony and a big brown horse with a little white on it. The brown horse was very nice. Bonnie thought they had met before, in her dreams. She remembered riding him in a big competition. The horse's name was Maverick. Bonnie couldn't resist the temptation to ride him. She found a saddle and bridle and put them on Maverick. She felt like a queen on the horse, and she was happy. She remembered her old nickname, 'Queen Bee', and laughed.
Bonnie rode Maverick around the paddock, feeling free and happy. She told Maverick that he was the best horse she had ever ridden, and she meant it. She thought they could be good friends if she stayed at the school.

'I've met Cody Simpson before and I'm impressed by his calm confidence. He's a 15-year-old Australian who has already released many popular songs. So, how did a relaxed surfer boy end up performing in front of thousands of fans? 'I started playing the guitar when I was six and writing songs when I was seven,' Cody says, remembering how it all began. 'But I was also swimming and surfing a lot. Those were the things that mattered most to me back then. I was 13 and in high school, and then I posted some videos online.'
These videos changed everything. He started with a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans asked for more videos, so Cody recorded some more at home. The response was amazing. Cody was a good swimmer and was training with top coaches. But then record labels contacted him, and he had to make a difficult choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming or take a big risk and move to the US with his family. Cody decided to take the risk. 'It was hard for me - especially at such a young age - to choose a career for myself. Can you imagine trying to figure out what you want to do for the rest of your life at 12 or 13?' He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. 'It was a big surprise for most people. I'm a quiet person,' he says, remembering their shocked expressions.
Cody packed his bags and moved to the US with his family, giving up one dream to pursue another. Although his family keeps a low profile and isn't involved in his career, they're always there for him. Cody says it's important to surround yourself with good people to stay grounded. We all have doubts sometimes. 'Sometimes when I'm alone, I think about how my decision affected my little brother and sister. My little brother is eight and travels the world, doing school on the road. He doesn't have a regular life,' Cody admits. 'I worry about that sometimes, but my family always reassures me that they're here to support me.'
Success comes from being brave and taking risks. 'It all happened so fast and unexpectedly,' Cody says. 'Now, I'm going to countries I never thought I'd visit and performing in front of thousands of fans. It's like something many people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won't last forever.'

I woke up early and went to the window. I lifted the curtain and looked out at the river. The ice was melting and there was a crack in it. I could see the wall of sandbags to protect the buildings from flooding. I remembered helping to put them there last week. My grandfather didn't seem to care that I did a good job.
I looked at the river and saw a dark patch of water where the factory's pipe was releasing warm water. I was getting ready to go kayaking. I put on my wetsuit and checked my lucky chain, which my grandfather brought back from a trip to South America. I also have his diary, which I keep under my pillow.
I went to the kitchen to get a banana. My mom was making breakfast. She reminded me to be careful on the river. I said goodbye and headed out to the boathouse.
As I was leaving, I bumped into my grandfather. He was grumpy and asked where I was going. I told him I was going kayaking. He said I didn't need to train because I didn't win the competition. I ignored him and went to the boathouse.
My mom came out and told me not to mind my grandfather. He's been acting strange lately. I tried to be patient with him because I used to look up to him. I want to be like him when I grow up and have my own adventures.

Mum took Jess by the arm and said, 'Come with me.' Jess followed her to the study and saw a painting on the table. It was one of Grandpa's, but it was different from his other paintings. It was a river, but not a real one. The riverbank was very small and green, and the water was pale and seemed to go on forever. There were no animals, birds, or people in the picture. Jess was fascinated by it. Mum said, 'It has a name.' Jess didn't know what to make of it. Grandpa never gave his paintings names. Mum turned the picture over and showed Jess the words 'River Boy'. Jess read them out loud. 'River Boy' seemed important, but she didn't know why. Mum said, 'There's no boy in the picture.' Jess was surprised. Grandpa never did that. Mum had asked him about the painting, and he said it was strange to give it a name. He said that artists don't need to explain their paintings to everyone who looks at them. He said that each painting has its own life and its own language, and people either understand it or they don't. Mum said she was hoping Jess might know something about the painting because Jess was like a muse to Grandpa. A muse is someone who inspires an artist. Jess knew what the word meant, but she didn't think Grandpa meant her. She thought he meant a goddess or a mythical creature. She didn't think anyone could inspire Grandpa, who was a very independent person. 'He doesn't need me to inspire him,' she said. 'He's been painting all his life.'

"When I woke up this morning, I didn't mean to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I was trying to find a way to fit a special cabinet into a corner of my room. The cabinet was given to me by my grandmother. It's small and has a pretty design on it. I was excited to get it because I love collecting things like shells and stones.
The problem was that the cabinet is shaped like a triangle and needs to fit into a corner. My room is small and has only two corners. I was trying to think of a solution, and then it came to me: I could cut a hole in the carpet. It seemed like a good idea at the time, but now I'm not so sure. Sometimes I do things without thinking them through, and then I wonder why I did them.
I was trying to be clever and think outside the box, like my dad always tells me to do. But now I'm not sure if it was a good idea. I hope my dad won't be too upset with me."

"The TV series 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live in the walls and floors of a house. They take things from the normal-sized people to survive. When I directed the TV series, I knew it would be hard to please everyone who loves the book. I used the original drawings from the book to make sure it was right. The author wanted the series to be from the Borrowers' point of view, not from a human's. This made filming tricky. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so we had to film them from far away. When we filmed the big people's surroundings, we had to crawl on the ground. We never used high cameras except for special shots. One big challenge was making the shadows look right. We developed a special way to do this. After the series was finished, a famous director, George Lucas, called me to ask how we did it. We built a special set for the Borrowers' home under the floorboards. It was strange but fun. The actors had to carry big things like scissors and coins, which made the crew laugh. In one scene, the Borrowers go down a drain. The actors had to be swept down a tunnel and said it was scary. I wanted the costumes to look like doll clothes, so they were heavy and stiff. This made it hard for the actors to move. The weather was hot during filming, and the actors didn't like the costumes. Most of the scenes were filmed with the actors separated from their surroundings. We used a blue screen and I drew pictures of each scene to show the actors what to do. I drew 2,000 pictures in total! It was a lot of work, but the series turned out well and people liked it."

My mom drops me off at my new school, Palm Grove High. She looks around nervously, making sure there are no journalists. I tell her everything will be fine. She kisses my cheek and leaves me to start my new school. I wanted to leave my old life and tour tutors behind. I want to meet normal kids, like those with parents who work 9 to 5 or cut grass. I walk into the school office and ask for my schedule. The secretary is not very friendly. I tell her my name is Desert McGraw. She types it into the computer and gives me my schedule. My first class is English Literature. I'm a little late, but I know the way to the classroom. I take a deep breath and go in. The teacher is already taking roll. I slip into the last desk and try to look normal. The girl next to me smiles and says my shoes are nice. I look down and realize I shouldn't have worn them. She introduces herself as Becca. We start talking and I tell her my dad is an artist. She doesn't seem interested. I'm happy to have someone to talk to, even if she doesn't care about my dad's job.

'American teenagers have a lot of responsibilities. They are expected to do well in school, have a part-time job, volunteer, and be active in their communities. It's not enough to just get average grades; they need to excel in all areas. Many people think that teenagers are lazy, selfish, and reckless, but this is not always true. Teenager Kristen Loose says that people often assume that they spend too much time on their phones and TV, but this is not the case. She uses her phone to stay organized and connected with others, not just to text her friends. Many teenagers have to work hard to balance their schoolwork, extracurricular activities, jobs, and family responsibilities. They often get very little sleep and have to wake up early to do it all again the next day. Despite the pressure, many teenagers are involved in volunteer work and try to make a positive impact in their communities. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says that she focuses on volunteer work and helping others, not just on her own interests. She believes that the stereotype of teenagers as selfish and lazy is not accurate. Who knows what the stereotype will be in 20 years, but teenagers will continue to prove it wrong and make a difference in the world.'

'The Earth to Sky Calculus Club is a group of teenagers who live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US. They launch balloons into space, around 35 km above the Earth's surface. They do this as a science project, but it's also an adventure. They want to record shooting stars, which are bright lights in the sky when a rock or piece of metal enters the Earth's atmosphere.
One weekend, I joined them to launch a new balloon. They put a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer inside a special box attached to the balloon. They also put GPS trackers on the outside to find it later. The balloon grew bigger and bigger until it was as big as a small car.
When it was time to launch, they counted down and the balloon went up. Some of them followed it with flashlights, shining it in the moonless sky. They were all quiet and felt a sense of wonder. Then the balloon disappeared.
After the launch, most of the students went home, but some stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountain and looked at the very clear sky. I saw a boy fall asleep in his sleeping bag. 'We're the only ones talking,' said one girl. 'I know,' whispered another.
As the balloon went up, it got thinner air and got bigger and bigger until it popped. A parachute helped the box come back down safely. The students would find it the next day using the GPS trackers.
Getting it back isn't easy, but that's part of the fun. The lunch box often lands in the middle of nowhere, so they have to drive or walk to get it. On this occasion, it took them 11 hours to find it. It was in a canyon, high on a rock, near a waterfall. The camera didn't record any shooting stars, but they could talk about the effects of atmospheric waves and how they work above mountain ridges. And they had a new story to tell.'

Chloe Morgan didn't like science or palaeontology when she was younger. But when she was 15, she helped her younger brother with a school project and read an article about dinosaurs. She was amazed and decided to learn more. She met a professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was kind and patient with her questions.
Chloe thinks that movies and TV shows often show palaeontologists in a bad light. They are usually portrayed as weird or boring people who don't know how to talk to others. But Chloe's job is actually very varied. She digs up dinosaur bones, studies fossils, and writes articles. She also has to explain science to the public.
Chloe believes it's important to help young people understand science and appreciate the natural world. She likes to talk to children about dinosaurs because it can make them interested in other areas of science too. Recently, she worked on a TV documentary about dinosaurs and was happy to see that it was accurate and showed how much we've learned about dinosaurs.
Chloe thinks that dinosaurs are still fascinating because they are unknown and exciting. They remind us that there is still much to discover and learn. Palaeontology is a way to travel back in time and learn about the past.

'When you're on a car trip with your family, even when you're just six years old, you know you're not there yet, even when you keep asking "Are we there yet?" And when you finally get there, it's not "there" anymore, it's "here". So, you should ask "Are we here yet?" instead. I'm sure parents get tired of answering "Are we there yet?" over and over again. In fact, being in the back seat can be quite comfortable. You can watch movies, listen to music, or do some puzzles while looking at the nice views outside. And your parents will take care of everything, like giving you snacks and drinks. But sometimes, things can get a bit crazy. My brother, Tim, would sometimes put his foot on my side of the seat, and then we would fight. Our parents would have to stop the car and separate us. After that, we would calm down and the scenic views would continue. Sometimes, I would try to read a book, but then I would feel a cold breeze on my arm. It was coming from my brother, who was sitting next to me and blowing on me on purpose. I got angry and we had another fight. Our dad has some strategies to deal with us kids on the back seat. For example, he would say "We're here" when we asked "Are we there yet?", even when we were still on the highway. That would keep us quiet for a while. You know you're finally "there" when the grown-ups get out of the car and go away from us kids who have been bothering them for hours. So, remember: if your parents are still near, the answer is "no, you're not there yet".'

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a caf in Oxford where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They want to create a place where people can socialize and have fun together, away from their phones and screens. The games they play are called 'Eurogames' and are known for being friendly and fun. The first game of this type was 'The Settlers of Catan', where players build settlements and trade resources. Another popular game is 'Pandemic', where players work together to solve problems. The game designer, Matt Leacock, was inspired by a game called 'Lord of the Rings' and wanted to create a game that would bring people together. He was frustrated with games as a child, so he started designing his own. The growth of video games has actually helped the popularity of board games, as people are now more open to playing games with others. Some people who used to play video games online are now looking for ways to play with others in person. John and Zuzi's caf is a popular place where people can do just that.

Jamie Scott has written and produced many popular songs in the UK. His story shows that perseverance is important in the music industry, even when things don't go as planned at first. His mother was a great singer and taught him to play the guitar. He listened to local radio stations as a child, which influenced his music taste. Jamie started playing the piano at school and wrote songs during his lunch breaks. He had to choose between playing tennis at a high level and pursuing music. He chose music because it was what he really wanted to do.
At 17, Jamie left school to try to become a performer. He formed a duo with a friend, but they didn't share the same passion for music. Jamie's parents gave him a deadline to make it in the music industry, and if he didn't, he would have to get a job. After some close calls with record labels, Jamie was signed to a music publisher at 19. However, he had to split from his friend and work behind the scenes instead of on stage.
Jamie found success as a songwriter, writing for other artists. He believes that writing songs that can be successful is not shameful, but rather a goal to strive for. He thinks that writing a song that many people will like is a great achievement. Jamie is honest about his goals and doesn't worry about what others think. He wants to write songs that are popular and will be remembered.

Tony Connor is a famous street trials cyclist. He does amazing things on his bike, like jumping from one place to another. People watch him online and he has a lot of fans. I met him at a BMX park and was amazed by his skills. He's very brave and creative. He thinks carefully before doing a stunt and explains what he's going to do. Sometimes I didn't think he could do it, but he always does. After he finishes a stunt, he seems a bit downbeat and doesn't like being famous. He likes doing things, not talking about them. He's grateful for the technology that helps him make a living doing what he loves. He's not complaining, but he doesn't like how people spend too much time looking at screens. He fell a few times while we were at the park, but he got up and kept trying until he got it right. Some people think he's reckless, but he says they don't understand the sport. He takes advice from experts to minimize the risks. He knows it's important to be aware of the dangers and he's not addicted to risk. He spends a lot of time planning and preparing before doing a new stunt. He knows he has to stay calm before he jumps.
